channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Laurent Fabius, French Foreign Minister, Visits Iran
item.description: The visit by Mr. Fabius was one of the first in what was likely to be a string of trips by European officials seeking closer ties with Iran.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, right, of Iran with his French counterpart, Laurent Fabius, in Tehran on Wednesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Scavengers Are India’s Real Recyclers
item.description: If Modi really wants to create wealth out of waste, there is a workforce waiting for him.
item.dc:creator: RAGHU KARNAD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Christopher K. Johnson on the Heavy Thumb of Xi Jinping
item.description: A senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies explains why he thinks President Xi Jinping is distinctly more powerful than his recent predecessors and is recasting the rules of Chinese politics.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Christopher K. Johnson, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Appearing Drunk on Television, Chinese Official Faces Inquiry
item.description: When residents of a polluted village went to complain to the government, an official appeared to be so drunk that he was not able to offer much of a response, Henan Television reported. The display was captured on video and posted online.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: At War Blog: Lt. Col. Kate Germano on the Marines and Women
item.description: Colonel Germano was relieved of command at Parris Island in June under circumstances that remain contentious, and then the Marine Corps Gazette decided not to print an article of hers that had been scheduled. It is now printed here.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Kate Germano, who took command of the Marine Corps’ all-women boot camp, was . The Corps said her Marines had been mistreated; she said her ability to command had been undermined.

item.title: Obama, on China’s Turf, Presents U.S. as a Better Partner for Africa
item.description: Without quite saying so explicitly, the president made the argument that, when it comes to trade, Washington offers a more empowering vision for the future.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama toured the Faffa Foods factory in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Tuesday. During his visit to Africa, Mr. Obama has essentially made the argument that Washington offers a better, more empowering vision for the continent’s future than China does.

item.title: Reports of Taliban Leader Mullah Omar’s Death Spur Afghan Inquiry
item.description: A presidential spokesman said an investigation had been ordered into claims by breakaway insurgents that the elusive Taliban chief was dead, which has been rumored before.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Malik Ishaq, Militant Leader in Pakistan, Is Said to Die in Attack on Police Convoy
item.description: The leader of Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, a banned extremist group, died in a shootout after armed supporters tried to free him from police custody, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and WAQAR GILLANI
item.media:description: Pakistani police officers escorting the head of Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, Malik Ishaq, at the High Court in Lahore on Dec. 22.

item.title: Report Cites Possible War Crimes in Israeli Hunt for Ambushed Soldier
item.description: Amnesty International’s inquiry reconstructs a 2014 episode in the Gaza Strip, now called Black Friday, which continues to cause international ripples a year later.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Al Mezan Center for Human Rights
item.media:description: Images taken by the Al Mezan Center for Human Rights, a Palestinian nongovernmental organization, showing the aftermath of the Israeli strikes in Rafah.

item.title: How Germany Prevailed in the Greek Bailout
item.description: Germany’s patience and brinkmanship, while exploiting mistakes made by the Athens government under Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, led the way to a Berlin consensus.
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece at an anti-austerity rally this month. When his left-wing radical Syriza party won the Greek election in January, it was determined to change the entire playing field for European economic policy.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Britain Is Losing Against ISIS Recruitment Tactics
item.description: A marketing pitch has swayed hundreds of young British Muslims into believing the Islamic State's utopian vision.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Samuel Pisar Dies at 86; Lawyer and Adviser Survived Nazi Camps
item.description: Mr. Pisar survived the Holocaust to create a life of accomplishment, including becoming an adviser to John F. Kennedy, whom he met at Harvard, and as a lawyer to corporate executives and movie stars.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Ed Alcock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Samuel Pisar in 2009. He wrote new words for Leonard Bernstein’s “Kaddish” Symphony.

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal Temple Halts Animal Sacrifices
item.description: A temple in southern Nepal known for the mass slaughter of animals at a festival every five years has indefinitely banned animal sacrifice.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: U.N. Council to Vote on Creating Tribunal On Downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight
item.description: The jetliner is believed to have been destroyed by a surface-to-air missile fired from territory controlled by pro-Russia separatists in eastern Ukraine
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rights Advocates, and a Monk, Oppose Beijing’s Winter Olympics Bid
item.description: Opponents of the effort by China are citing a widening crackdown on rights defense lawyers, political activists and ethnic minorities.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN and ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Golog Jigme, an exiled Tibetan monk, has urged that Beijing not be awarded the 2022 Winter Games.

item.title: Hundreds of Migrants Try to Cross English Channel on Freight Trains
item.description: Group after group of migrants made their way to the Eurotunnel compound in Calais overnight on Monday, climbing over fences and other barriers in a desperate bid to reach Britain.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Nikkei Vies for Global Clout With Splurge on The Financial Times
item.description: The Japanese business newspaper hopes that the $1.3 billion purchase will give it a trophy that can compete with major papers in Europe and America.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Newspapers for sale in Japan. The Japanese paper Nikkei is buying The Financial Times, of Britain.

item.title: Brazil Arrests Nuclear Chief in Widening of Graft Case
item.description: Othon Luiz Pinheiro da Silva is accused of taking more than $1.3 million in bribes as chief executive of Eletronuclear, a company that operates nuclear plants.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Top American Commander Warns U.N. That Too Few Carry Efforts for Peace
item.description: The top American military commander urged United Nations member states on Tuesday to increase their commitments to its global peacekeeping forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: ‘Nobody Should Be President for Life,’ Obama Tells Africa
item.description: President Obama took on one of the region’s most enduring obstacles to democratic progress: its history of one-man rule by leaders who enrich themselves and hang onto power.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Leaving Ethiopia, where he gently urged greater progress, the president boarded Air Force One.
